results.title: Drums for a holiday
results.creator_credit: A R Taylor, Peter Stiles and Anglo-Scottish Pictures
results.brief_description: This film looks at the Gold Coast (now Ghana), its history, industries and export trade in cotton and cocoa, and social and political life. Half of the world’s cocoa comes from this region, and the harvesting, fermenting, drying, grading according to quality, and selling and shipping of the beans is illustrated. The film records a ceremonial parade to the local Durbar attended by the King of Ashanti, village Chiefs, and British representatives. Commentary by Leo Genn; photography by Stanley Gooze and edited by John Ferris

results.title: Drummer Hoff
results.creator_credit: Gene Deitch, Morton Schindel, William L Snyder, Kratky Film and Weston Woods Studios
results.brief_description: This film is a lively folk verse about the building of a cannon called Sultan. Brightly dressed in full uniform each soldier brings a part of the remarkable machine. Based on the book by Ed and Barbara Emberley and adapted by Gene Deitch.

results.title: Drugs, use or abuse
results.brief_description: Beginning with various types of beneficial drugs, the film moves to excessive use, stimulants and depressants, damaging chemicals in drugs, psychological dependence and forms of harmful drugs. Presents basic information about drugs and moves the viewer towards their own conclusion.

results.title: Drugs - better dead?
results.brief_description: An undramatised documentary which shows the harrowing effects of drug misuse. Young addicts and ex-addicts give accounts of what life is like on various drugs, how they experience withdrawal symptoms and their need for more and more money to buy the drugs. Glimpses are seen of a post-mortem examination being conducted on the body of a young female addict.

results.title: Drugs Are Not the Problem
results.brief_description: In themselves drugs are not a problem but their abuse is. The film shows young people using various drugs and the penultimate consequence of addiction. There is a clear, diagrammatic representation of how the human mind and nervous system work and how drugs affect them. Above all, the film repeatedly points out that the human mind is capable of the greatest powers.

results.title: Drugs and you
results.brief_description: A unique 5-minute audio-visual tool designed to stimulate frank student discussion on drug taking. It consists of five separate 30 second TV spots, interspersed with questions programmed between each commercial.

results.title: Drugs and the very young
results.creator_credit: Joanne M Mock and KQED-TV (Television station : San Francisco, Calif.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Drugs: the children are choosing”.
The fourth film in the series suggests reasons why teenagers may begin to experiment with drugs. Using simulated everyday situations shows how children learn from example that drugs can bring pleasure and relief. Finally an expert outlines a program which presents real alternatives.

results.title: Drugs and the nervous system. - Rev. ed.
results.brief_description: This film explains the serious disruption of the nervous system caused by drugs: aeroplane glue, stimulants (amphetamines), depressants (barbiturates, opiates), marijuana and LSD. This film is animated and is suitable for young children (Early Adolescence).

results.title: Drugs and the nervous system
results.brief_description: An animated film explaining how drugs acting on the nervous system affect the body, emphasising the danger of indiscriminate use of common drugs taking aspirin as an example. Discusses the harmful effects of narcotics, stimulants and depressants and hallucinogens. Suitable for children aged from 13 years onwards.

results.title: Drugs and beyond
results.creator_credit: Extension Media Center, University of California
results.brief_description: Raises the question of whether a variety of mind controlling substances can be used for positive purposes such as increased learning power, memory stimulation, accelerated maturing processes, mood change or tension control. The emphasis is on manipulation of consciousness or behaviour rather than alteration or awareness expansion.
